Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Story: The store was packed, the line at my register snaking past the candy racks. My fingers flew over the keys, scanning groceries, counting change, trying to keep the line moving. My phone buzzed in my apron pocket—Mom’s name lit up the screen. It was Sunday, our weekly call, the one time she expected to hear my voice, to know I was okay, to share her stories and worries. I glanced at the clock. If I didn’t answer, she’d worry, maybe think something was wrong. But the customers were restless, shifting from foot to foot, some already sighing loudly. My manager had reminded us just this morning: no distractions, no phones, accuracy above all. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my mother’s gentle expectation for connection, the store’s demand for flawless, undivided attention. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the two roles, knowing I couldn’t satisfy both at once.
